node.title: [Geochemistry module][Coupling of transportation and reactions]
node.bodyText:
Dear users,
I would like to use geochemistry module for coupling of transportation and chemical reactions.
As far as I know, there are three ways to couple the transportation and chemical reactions.

Fully coupling
Solve transportation -> Solve chemical reactions.
Itration of Solve transporation -> Solve chemical reactions

Among these three types, which method is used in the Geochemistry module?
Cheers,
Q
The answer is (2) and (3).   You might find the quite detailed documentation found at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/geochemistry/index.html useful.
Thank you for your answer! Its great helpful for me~! Cheers

node.title: Vector Valued Variables in MultApp
node.bodyText: I am looking to use multi-app to pull velocity (vector) data from a transient Naiver Stokes solution into a separate app that imposes the values of the transient solution on to a steady state domain. For instance if I'm using the transient values for the initial conditions for a steady state solutions. Can this be accomplished by use of an existing kernel, aux kernel, or anything? In my case the two mesh domains share the same dimensions and mesh densities.

Hello
This is Navier Stokes finite element or finite volume ?
If they use the same mesh you can use the MultiAppCopyTrasnfer on the components of the velocity.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/transfers/MultiAppCopyTransfer.html
In FE, you can use this https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/VectorVariableComponentAux.html to retrieve velocity components.
Then you can initialize the velocity component by component.
In FV it's simple, transfer directly to the right variable velocity component.
In FE you ll have to create a new object, a BuildVectorVariableAux, similar to this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/BuildArrayVariableAux.html
Let us know if you need help with this
An example of a VectorAuxkernel is this one:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/src/auxkernels/VectorFunctionAux.C
Guillaume
Thank you for the reply. I am using FE. I will review the referenced links you provided, and reach out to you for additional guidance if I run into further roadblocks to my understanding.

I executed  MultiAppCopyTransfer on of the sample problems that uses MultiAppCopyTransfer, I also attempted to use it in a code that I developed. I keep getting the same error "Unable to locate object" each time. Is it possible that I will need to do and update and remake prior to being able to run this particular command?
What are you trying to copy? The vector variable or the variable components?
I was able to get MultiAppCopyTransfer to work properly when I used the components of a the vector or a scalar variable like Temperature. I must have been attempting to use velocity initially. Thanks

node.title: Dendrite Solidification code for binary alloy
node.bodyText: I am  interested in solving dendrite solidification problem for binary alloys.  I am having trouble implementing code for dendritic growth of binary alloys. Can you please help me out with some reference code for the same? Any resources will be of great help. Thank you very much!
@SudiptaBiswas Could you help with this?

You can find some of the solidification examples here,
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/tree/next/modules/phase_field/examples/anisotropic_interfaces
The examples that use the grand-potential-based model will be relevant for binary alloys.

You can find some of the solidification examples here, https://github.com/idaholab/moose/tree/next/modules/phase_field/examples/anisotropic_interfaces
The examples that use the grand-potential-based model will be relevant for binary alloys.

Hi，friends
I have a question.
How to use two order parameters with the kenerl ACInterfaceKobayashi1,ACInterfaceKobayashi2 and InterfaceOrientationMaterial.
Like op = eta1, op = eta2

node.title: Limiting Boundary Condition
node.bodyText:
Hi MOOSE users,
I'm wondering what is the most sensible way to implement the following condition at the boundaries?

Best Regards,
Robert

Hello
Depends on the equation.
Do you have an analytical form that you could integrate such that phi(x=some_number) = some_value (for Dirichlet, similar for Neumann) is equivalent to this limit condition ?
You could also just make a really big mesh and put that calculation on a computing cluster.
Guillaume

node.title: Using AbaqusUMATStress with generalized plane strain
node.bodyText:
This combo does not work as-is. Not sure if by design or just an oversight.
In poking around in the code for the generalized plane strain problem, it looks like the GeneralizedPlaneStrainUserObject requires an entry from the elasticity tensor to compute the Jacobian contribution for the out-of-plane scalar variable (see here). But the problem is that when using AbaqusUMATStress, a global elasticity tensor material does not always need to be built, and as such, MOOSE cannot access specific components of the tensor. The AbaqusUMATStress material does access the components of the tensor in UMAT-notation in order to contribute to the Jacobian for the displacement variables (I believe, here), but that information does not make it over to the GeneralizedPlaneStrainUserObject.
So it seems like the information that it needs to do generalized plane strain is available from the UMAT interface, I'm just not sure if there's an "easy" way to get at it from the GeneralizedPlaneStrainUserObject.

It was not in the statement of work. As far as I can see the way forward would involve a new GeneralizedUMATPlainStrain object that calls the UMAT to obtain both stress and the Jacobian component. The elasticity tensor is "secret" and might not even exist as such in a general UMAT.

node.title: Error in moose when submission to cluster
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I just re-install moose on the cluster of my institution and installed our own App for use.
The installation works fine and both moose and my app are good with the  ./run_tests.
However, when I submit it to HPC PBS work, there shows error like:
./c_pfor_am-opt: error while loading shared libraries: libsz.so.2: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
So I connect with IT and they copied the library libsz.so.2, then new error like:
./c_pfor_am-opt: error while loading shared libraries: libglpk.so.36: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
So they add this lib file again. Then the error back to libsz.so.2 again.
I feel getting stuck at it so I installed  libaec-1.0.4-1.el7.aarch64.rpm but it did not help.
Is it lacking of some file or lib necesasry in the cluster?
The version in cluster is CentOS Linux release 7.9.2009.
Please let me know if you have any suggestions and thank you very much in advance.
Best regards,
Daijun

My advice is to build and run on one of your compute nodes in an interactive fashion (qsub -I). It sounds as if the compute nodes do not have the same libraries and headers being made available on the head node.

node.title: How to define DiracKernel that is a function in space and time
node.bodyText:
Hi
I am trying to simulate an ultrasound push inside soft tissue. The push spatial distribution and its variation in time are given. I used to use ReporterPointSource to define point sources distributed in space. Now, how can I define the variation in time of those sources?

Hello
To make them vary in time you ll have to vary the reporter values.
What kind of reporter are you using?
I think you essentially need a vectoroffunctionpostprocessor but that doesnt exist rn. You can make one with this:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/FunctionValuePostprocessor.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/VectorOfPostprocessors.html
Guillaume
Guillaume

Thanks, @GiudGiud
I am using the CSVReader. I will look into those options.
CSVReader doesnt do time dependence sadly.

CSVReader doesnt do time dependence sadly.

So, generally, can we model a force that is varying in time and has user-defined spatial distribution through moose?
The force that I have is an impulse or a step function in time and has a spatial distribution that is given (at each node). Can we model this in moose?

Do you have a parsed expression for the function? If so that's the easiest.
How many time steps is there? If a small number we can hack something together with parsed expressions (if(t<t1, use function_1, else if t<t2, etc) easily.
Do you have the data only in a CSV format?
Other options could be pre-loaded in an Exodus file.
In the CSV file can the data be easily separated in different files for each time step?

For the ideal case, a parsed expression for the spatial distribution is not available. But I can figure out a simplified version of the force so that I can have parsed expression for it.
The data is available on a grid produced by a matlab script. So, I think it can be written in different formats.
Yes, I can separate the data for each time step in the CSV file.

Ok I need to sleuth for a bit through the docs to figure out what s the best option from CSV.
I think easiest will be to read a CSV file on every time step

Actually, these two functions can do time and space dependent CSV files
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/PiecewiseMultilinear.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/PiecewiseMulticonstant.html
from there you d need to link them up to the Dirac Kernels.
I think this one should work, but you ll need multiple of them
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/dirackernels/FunctionDiracSource.html
To work with the ReporterPointSource,
You could:

modify FunctionDiracSource to have multiple points
OR
modify FunctionValuePostprocessor to chose the point to evaluate the function at
OR
write a FunctionValuesVectpostprocessor to evaluate a given function at multiple points, specified in either a CSV file or with x/y/z vectors

Either of these options would be good to add to MOOSE

Thanks @GiudGiud
Actually, I found this UserForcingFunctionNodalKernel
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/nodalkernels/UserForcingFunctionNodalKernel.html
which I think will work fine combined with PiecewiseMulticonstant functions. The only issue would be that the user has to define the force values on all grid points. For example, if the user wanted to model only one point source in one location (let's say in the middle of the domain), the user must set zero force to all other points in the grid.
This feels like a very different object, so I m not sure. But if you say so then I m glad you have what you need!

node.title: Error message when change the input file in phase_field-mechanics$
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE workers ：
I recently find an module just suitable for my research ,phase_field-mechanics.which provide the input options of euler angles .howerer ,since there is a vacant in introduction documentation of combined modules .I wonder what input format  should I change to be suitable for grn_36_test_2D.tex .I change the file into grain file exported from OIM ,and the following errdor message occured > I attached the file I used in this module .
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "hex_ic", of type "PolycrystalHex".
PolycrystalHex requires a square or cubic number depending on the mesh dimension
Stack frames: 16
0: libMesh::print_trace(std::ostream&)
1: moose::internal::mooseErrorRaw(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator >, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator >)
2: callMooseErrorRaw(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator >&, MooseApp*)
3: /home/zengfanyi/projects/moose/modules/phase_field/lib/libphase_field-opt.so.0(+0x28ae74) [0x7f00a2f90e74]
4: PolycrystalHex::precomputeGrainStructure()
5: PolycrystalUserObjectBase::execute()
6: FEProblemBase::joinAndFinalize(TheWarehouse::QueryCache<>, bool)
7: FEProblemBase::computeUserObjectsInternal(MooseEnumItem const&, Moose::AuxGroup const&, TheWarehouse::QueryCache<>&)
8: FEProblemBase::computeUserObjects(MooseEnumItem const&, Moose::AuxGroup const&)
9: FEProblemBase::initialSetup()
10: Transient::init()
11: MooseApp::executeExecutioner()
12: MooseApp::run()
13: /home/zengfanyi/projects/moose/modules/combined/combined-opt(+0x527e) [0x561245c7127e]
14: __libc_start_main
15: /home/zengfanyi/projects/moose/modules/combined/combined-opt(+0x550d) [0x561245c7150d]
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
[unset]: write_line error; fd=-1 buf=:cmd=abort exitcode=1
:
system msg for write_line failure : Bad file descriptor
can  you help me fix this .
test.zip

This IC tries to fit n x n hexagons in a 2D simulation, where n is an integer, or n x n x n in 3D. So, you need to supply a grain number that is a square of that integer for a 2D simulation or the cube of that integer for 3D. So, for a 2D simulation, you need to supply grain_num = 4, 9, 16 etc. to get 2 x 2, 3 x 3, 4 x 4 etc.

node.title: Using RayTracing module to trace the transient position of particles in Fluid flow
node.bodyText:
I am trying to trace ~ 100 - 1000 mass points inside a fluid flow. I have a UserOject that can update the position of each mass particle with time, however, I want to output the trajectory of those particles alongside the fluid simulation.
I have checked the Ray Tracing module which has a RayTracingExodus where the trajectory of the rays are saved.
Is it possible to use the same for saving the transient position of all the particles during the fluid flow? Or could you please suggest a better way to accomplish this?

Hello
The RayTracingExodus should be the rays/trajectories of these displacements. And you only want the positions ?
Am I understanding this right?
Guillaume

Hi!
Yes, I want to store the trajectories of those particles using RayTracingExodus. Is it possible?

But you are not using the RayTracing module right now?
If not then no, the RayTracingExodus is meant for the RayTracing module. The good news is that if you rework your code to use ray tracing instead of the custom UO, then you get a TON of stuff working (mesh decomposition, asynchronous communication, output, integration capabilities etc)
If you are then it should just work and if it doesnt please let us know what you see in the output.

if you are not using RayTracing and want to persist using a UO, then you should look a building a custom vector postprocessor, saving the positions for each mass point, then write a lil python visualization tool to plot positions from a CSV file. I do not recommend that
Are you doing this for the Material Point Method btw? We have had some progress looking at this with the RayTracing module, maybe we could share that with you

Thank you very much for your response. Our initial plan was to save the positions in CSV and use python to visualize the trajectories of each particle. However, as we have more than 1000 particles, it might not be as effective.
We are not using MPM, For the motion of those particles, we employ a kinematic equation based on Gaussian points. Could we use Ray Tracing kernels for implementing the kinematic equation?

How do you determine the acceleration of the particle?
What comes into play? Local fields? Other particles?
By Gaussian points you mean you need to refer to a local elemental quadrature?

node.title: How to use positions in the mesh inside a function
node.bodyText:
Hi!
I am using coord_type = RZ, for a polar mesh.
I want to use an equation that is dependent on space coordinates r and θ in my mesh. Is there an easy way to reference the positions in a function, I am thinking ParsedMaterial?
If I need to use the absolute value and the sign function (separately), do I write them the same in moose as I would in a C++ code? Is there a handbook where I can search this thing, I couldn’t find anything on Google or the website?
Best regards
Karl

Hello
So RZ is RZ not Rtheta, we dont actually support Rtheta right now. Closest thing is actually 2D-XY really.
For positions, you can pass x, y, z in parsed expressions. In the parsed material it might not process it right but you can define a function, like a parsed function
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/MooseParsedFunction.html
and then pass it in the parsed material.
The fparser documentation (the parser we use) is there: https://fparser.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
Absolute should be |x| I think. and sign might not be supported, if you can write : if(x<0,-1,1)
Guillaume
also note in RZ, x is R and y is Z, so they should be referred as such in the parsed expressions
